De curacio de dislocacio de malassen, so es de la junctura que es entre·l bras e la ma.	Of the treatment for a dislocation of the elbow, that is to say of the joint which is between the arm and the hand.
Malassen de la ma alcunas vetz es deslocada, e la reduccio de la dislocacio de lu es leugiera, e·l contrari es de las autras juncturas, mays empero cove que sia velocitat en la reduccio de lu en la hora en la qual es deslocada, denant que le loc sia apostemat o que accida en lu apostema caut.	A dislocation of the hand happens sometimes, and the reduction of it is easy, and on the contrary it is not so in other joints, but however it is necessary that there be speed in its reduction at the time when it is dislocated, before the place be inflamed or a suppurative inflammation occur on it.
E la reduccio de la dislocacio de lu es que tu pauses la junctura de la ma del malaute sobre una taula e le ministre extenda la ma de aquel, e le metge pause la sua ma o o la sua palma sobre la iminencia de la junctura, e empellisca aquela entro que retorne al sieu loc.	And the reduction of the dislocation is that you place the joint of the patient's hand on a table and have them extend their hand, and then the doctor places his hand or his palm above the joint, and pushes it in until it returns to its place.
Mays empero cove que sia considerat si la palma ja es ostada al ventre de la ma, lahoras le malaute pause le dos de la sua ma sobre una taula deves la extencio e la reduccio; e si la dislocacio es precedent deves le dos de la ma, lahoras sia la posicio de la ma de aquel intrinicequement sobre la taula, per so que la ma del metge caja sobre aquela iminencia de la junctura.	But it is necessary to consider if the palm is already in the way of the elbow of the hand, then the patient must place their forearm on a table for extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is anterior, then the forearm of the patient shall be the position of the hand of that person inherently on the table, so that the hand of the doctor can lie over that joint.
E donc si retorna tantost, bon es; e sino, lahoras strenh aquela am empastre cedant le apostema e layssa aquel; e no iteres aquo, quar sino, no soferta ni no podes sobre la reduccio de lu pus que passan a lu dias.	Entonces, si se reduce con facilidad, bien está. Pero si no se reduce inmediatamente, entonces debes aplicar fuerza suavemente mientras el paciente cede en el supuración y deja que se forme la costra; y no lo intentes de nuevo, porque sino, no podrás lograr la reducción del desgarro en más días.
Mays empero la junctura roman segon la sua tortuositat; e no notz al malaute alcuna causa, sino que la ma es mollificada e no pot strenher alcuna causa; lahoras sapias que les nervis son trincatz o trissatz, e lahoras no es engen en lu sino que sia strenhuda am cauteri prop le cazament de lu e fort leu aquo confereys alcuna causa.	Pero si la articulación sigue siendo rígida según su deformidad; y no mencionar al paciente ninguna lesión, sino que la mano está blanda y no puede ser fortalecida por ninguna fuerza; entonces sabrás que los nervios están atrapados o dañados, y en ese caso no es recomendable aplicar fuerza ni tampoco cauterizarlo con fuego, porque esto podría empeorar la situación.
Donc cum malassem es retornada, lahoras pausa sobre lu empastre le qual havem recomtat, e sia layssat e strenhut per v dias; e aprop sia desliat e sia layssat e la ma de lu sia excercitada.	Una vez que el paciente ha recuperado la movilidad en la articulación, entonces debes colocar sobre la supuración el emplasto que hemos recomendado y dejarlo allí durante 5 días; después de lo cual se debe quitar y la mano del paciente deberá ser ejercitada.

De la curacio de dislocacio dels ditz.	Capítulo XXIX: De la curación de las dislocaciones.
Alcunas veguadas so dislocatz les ditz a tota partida.	Some joints have been dislocated completely.
E quan es dislocat alcun dit de aquels al dos de la palma o al ventre de lu, lahoras sten le dit e impelleys la dislocacio de lu am les tieus pouses, entro que retorne.	And when some of these fingers are dislocated at the wrist or in the patient's abdomen, we press hard on the finger and push the dislocation towards the joint spaces, until it returns.
E aprop sostenta le cap del dit, e suspen aquel deves la part a la qual es dislocat, e layssa aquel per dos dias.	And after that, support the head of the finger and suspend it from above at the point where it is dislocated, and let it stay like that for two days.
E aprop suspen aquel e exten aquel entro que dreyt sia engualhat en aquel sieu dia.	And after that, hang it down and stretch it until it is straight in its own time.
E quan sira noyt, lia aquel segon aquela narracio, e no cesses desliar aquel en le dia e exercitar am movement, e lia aquel en la noyt; e fay aquo per alcus dias entro que sia streyt.	And at night, tie it up according to that narration, and don't stop untwisting it in the day and exercising it with movements, and tie it up at night; and do this for some days until it is straight.
E fay semblant am aquo, si es dislocat al ventre de la ma, e lia aquel ad aquela partida e fay am aquo la tieua primiera operacio, entro que sia sanat.	And do the same thing if it is dislocated at the wrist of the hand and tie it up to that part and perform your first operation again, until it heals.
E semblantment fay am aquo quan es dislocat a las autres partidas.	And similarly do this when it is dislocated in other parts. (Note: This text appears to be written in an old form of Catalan or Occitan, and may require some expertise to fully understand.)
Capitol .xxx.	It looks like the end of a medieval manuscript! "Capitol" likely means "Chapter" in Latin, and ".xxx." indicates the end of chapter 30. The text you provided seems to be a medical treatise or handbook, possibly from the Middle Ages. If you'd like to share more, I'd be happy to help decipher it!
De la curacio de dislocacio dels spondils del dos.	It seems we've entered a specific chapter on a medieval medical text.
Quan accideys ad alcun dels spondils del dos o del col dislocacio complida, e so remaugutz motz spondils de lors locs, lahoras en aquela no es curacio, quar la mort se coyta al malaute.	When dislocation occurs in any of the vertebrae of the back or neck, and the displaced vertebrae are not restored to their place, then there is no cure for this condition, because death comes to the patient.
E senhal de aquo es que la egestio del malaute es fora-eyssida ses voluntat, e no pot retenir aquela; e motas veguadas so mollificatz alcus membres de lu o doas cambas de lu o dos brasses de lu, o un de aquels; o es remaugut un spondil de son loc, quar motas veguadas es remaugut e motas veguadas es fayta la remocio de aquels a quatre partidas.	And the sign of this is that the patient's urine comes out involuntarily and cannot be retained; and often times some members of his are softened, such as his legs or thighs or arms, or one of them; or a vertebrae is dislocated from its place, because it is often dislocated and often the dislocation is made in four parts.
Donc aquela ja es remauguda a las partidas detras e es nompnada gelbozitat.	So it is already dislocated backwards and is called fractured or broken.
Mays la curacio de lu es que lahoras consideras si la gelbozitat accidey de puerissia, quar lahoras en aquela no es curacio ni de aquela no es sanacio de tot.	However the treatment of him is that one considers if the fracture occurred in infancy, because then there is no cure for it nor a full recovery.
Mays en aquela que ve per cazement o per percussio o per semblant ad aquels, ja diyssero les Antics las manieras de curacio am sermo prolixs, del qual lo mays retorna am profieyt; mays yeu ja e abreujat de aquel del qual lo pauc escusa del trop de lu, per la mieua propinquitat a la entencio mieua exposicio, am la qual he aquo expausat et format ex instrument divers de aquel am le qual mostrero aquo e espausero aquel.	However, in cases where it occurs by accident or by impact or similar to these, the Ancients had already said the ways of treatment which I shall be prolix about, but what is most necessary returns for the greatest profit; however, I have abbreviated that from which little escapes from much, because of my proximity to my own understanding, in which I have exposed and formed this with various instruments similar to those by which I have shown and explained it.
E dic que en gelbosita que accideys de la partida denant en le pietz, no es engen ni sanacio de aquela; e semblantment en aquela que es fayta a dos latz.	And I say that in fractures that occur from the breaking of the shin bone, there is no remedy nor healing for them; and similarly in those that are broken into two places.
E de aquelas no es curada sino aquela que accideys en le dos propriament am aquo que yeu recomti.	And as for these, they cannot be cured unless the fracture occurs in such a way and place, as I recommend below.
E es que·l malaute sia extendut sobre la sua cara sobre pug engual prop de paret, e sia extendut dejos lu esturment molh per so que no sia lidit le pietz de lu.	And it is that the patient lies on his back with a wooden pillow under his head close to the wall, and that he has an instrument moistened with something between his legs to prevent his shin bone from being bruised.
E aprop un fust dreyt sia pausat, ficat en la terra en la extremitat del pug entorn le cap de lu, e autra fust en aviro les pes de lu en l’autra extremitat del pueg.	And bring a straight staff and place it on the ground near the head of the patient, and another staff at an angle, supporting his feet in the other extremity of the bed.
E·l ministre tengua le fust, e no sia fermat en fossa; e autre ministre tengua l’autre segon aquela forma.	And the attendant should hold the staff and not let it be fixed in a pit; and another attendant should hold the second staff in such a way.
E aprop envolopa sobre le cap del malaute e dejos les titillic liamen leon ferm; e exten la extremitat del liamel al fust le qual es deves le cap de lu, e lia aquel en lu; e aprop strenh l’autre liament sobre las ancas de lu les denols de lu, e deves las cambas de lu; e aprop ajusta totz les liamentz e lia aquels en l’autre fust le qual es deves les pes de lu.	And have someone wrap something around the patient's head and below it attach straps that are tightly tied; and extend the strap to the staff which is placed at the patient's head, and tie it there; and similarly tighten the other strap over the patient's buttocks, holding their legs, and then adjust all the straps and tie them to the second staff which is placed under the patient's feet.
E aprop le ministre cascu extenda le liament a la partida del fust, e no sian remaugutz les dos fustz e les liamentz dels sieus locs en les quals son ficatz, mays empero no so fermatz ayssi cum havem dit.	And have the attendant stretch the strap to the break of the staff, and the two staffs and straps should not be loosened from their places where they are fixed, but rather they should not be as firmly fastened as we have said.
E le metge pause las suas palmas sobre le spondil am fortaleza entro que retorne, o que pause sobre aquela una taula, e aprop que ajuste sobre la taula les sieus pes entro que retorne.	And the physician places his palms on the vertebra with great force until it returns to its place, or he places them on a table, and has him adjust himself onto the table by leaning on his hands until he returns.
Mays si no retorna per aquesta forma, lahoras pren una taula de la qual la latitut o la longitut sia en aviro de tres brassas, e cava en la paret de la qual havem dit que es prop le malaute un loc en le qual intre la extremitat de la taula.	But if it does not return to its place in this way, the physician takes a table whose length or width is three braccia [about 1.5 meters] wide and hollows out a space in the wall from which we have said that the patient lies, into which he inserts the end of the table.
E aprop pausa la maytat de la taula sobre le spondilh, e·l metge pause les sieus pes sobre l’autre extremitat, e estrenha be entro que le spondil sia coartat e que retorne al sieu loc.	And he places the majority of the table on the vertebra, and the physician places his own weight on the other end, tightening until the vertebra is compressed and returns to its place.
E si tu voles, obre am torn le qual es revolvut am la ma; e es que tu fiques en terra deves le cap del malaute en le derier del pug dos fustz, la longitut dels quals sia d’un bras, e deves le cap de lu en le derier del pug eyssament dos fustz; e sia la longitut que es entre quascun fust un palm, e ja es fayt en quascun fust trauc en le qual corr torn, e quascun sia mot fermat en terra per so que no sia maugut.	And if you wish, make a turn which is turned with the hand; and it is that you place yourself on the ground next to the patient's head at the end of the bed two staffs, the length of which is one arm, and place the patient's head at the end of the bed similarly two staffs; and be the distance between each staff a palm, and already made in each staff there are holes through which the turn will go, and each shall be tied down to the ground so that it may not move.
E sia mes un fust redon en le qual es le torn, e sia revolvut en les dos traucs dels dos fustz.	And there is one staff wrapped around which is the turn, and turned around in the two holes of the two staffs.
E en la extremitat de lu es un trauc en le qual es format le fust, la longueza del qual es un palm am aquo que es revolvut; e en les dos autres fustz es semblant de aquel.	And at the end of it is a hole in which the staff is formed, the length of which is a palm plus what is wrapped around, and similar to that are the two other staffs.
E aprop strenh les liamentz que has streyt en le pietz del malaute en le trau le qual es deves le cap de lu, e les liamentz que has streyts en las coyssas de lu en le torn le qual es deves les pes de lu.	And have the attendants tighten the straps that were tied to the patient's feet on the staff that is under their head, and the straps that were tightened around their legs in the turn that supports their weight.
E aprop deves quascun torn e stia un ministre que torssa le torn am la sua ma, e le metge engualhe le spondil segon que havem dit.	And have each turn and have an attendant who turns the turn with their hand, and the physician compresses the vertebra as we said.
E aquesta es la forma del torn:	It seems like you're about to describe the shape of the turn, but you left it incomplete. Would you like to finish describing it?
E aprop pus que le spondil es retornat, e le loc es engualhat, lahoras cove que pauses empastre exciccatiu am album de huou, e aprop estopa; e aprop pause sobre le empastre astela de taula de la qual la latitut sia de tres ditz o enviro aquels, e la longitut de lu sia quantitat que prengua le loc de la gelbositat, e sobre la partida del spondil sa.	It seems like you're providing instructions on how to treat the patient after the vertebra has been compressed. Here's a translation of what I think you're saying:
E aprop sia liat am liament le qual havem dit, e uze le malaute de nutriment subtil entro que sia sanat.	And now that we have tied up what we said earlier, use subtle nourishment on the patient until they are healed.
E si roman alcuna iminencia en le loc en la fi de la sanacio, lahoras cove que sian aministradas medicinas que moilifico e liniscan am aministracio de la taula per lonc temps, la qual havem recomtada; e ja es aministrada en aquel loc lamina de plom.	And if there is any urgency in the area at the end of recovery, hours are needed to administer medicines that will soften and calm the administration of the table for a long time, which we have recommended; and it has been administered in that place a sheet of lead.
E alcunas veguadas accideys imminencia en le derier dels spondils del dos, e es cujat per aquela dislocacio; e es aquel os le qual ja imineys per que no cove que sia fayta prosompcio a lu am aquesta medicina, quar fort leu fara a tu accidir mort.	And some times accidents happen at the end of the vertebrae of the neck, and it is caused by that dislocation; and that bone is so fragile that it does not need to be done a prognosis with this medicine, because very little would make you die.
Capitol .xxxi.	Chapter 31.
De curacio de anca dislocada.	Of the treatment of a dislocated shoulder.
Sapias que la junctura del ancha e la junctura del muscle no endeve sino dislocacio tant solament, e no accideys ad aquelas aquo que accideys a las autras juncturas de petita remocio e concavitat.	Know that the joint of the shoulder and the joint of the muscle do not stretch or dislocate except with such a displacement, and accidents do not occur to them like those that occur to other joints with slight movement and convexity.
E la junctura de la ancha es dislocada segon quatre manieyras, quar es dislocada a las partidas dedintz, o a las partidas defora, o a las partidas denant, o a las partidas detras.	And the joint of the shoulder is dislocated in four ways, because it can be dislocated upwards, downwards, forwards, or backwards.
E majorment es dislocada a las partidas dedintz, e pauc a las partidas denant o a las partidas detras.	And most often it is dislocated upward, and less often it is dislocated forward or backward.
E senhal de la dislocacio de lu a las partidas de dintz es quar, quan tu ajustas la camba del malaute sana am la malaute, es pus longua e·l denolh es pus heminent que de la sana, e·l malaute no pot doblar le sieu pe deves le lenguonar, e es le loc que siec le lengonar apostemat de apostema caut, per so que·l cap de la coyssa ja es pervengut aqui.	And the sign of dislocation upwards is that, when you join the arm of the sick person with the healthy one, it becomes longer and the elbow is higher than the healthy one, and the sick person cannot bend their own arm and the place where the elbow would normally be has become swollen from a swelling, therefore the head of the joint is already damaged here.
E·l senhal de aquel al qual accideys dislocacio es a las partidas defora, es que les accidentz de lu so contraris ad aquest accident.	And the sign that dislocation has occurred in him is that, outwardly, the accidents of it are contrary to this accident. (i.e. The arm is shorter and the elbow is lower than normal)
E senhal de aquel al qual accideys dislocacio a las partidas denant es quar expan la camba sieua segon compliment, mays empero no dobla aquela ses dolor que es en le denol, e si se perforsa ad anar e no pot sobre aquo a las partidas denant; e la urina de lu es retenguda e l’engonar de lu es apostemat, e deves la ambulacio de lu sobre le talo.	And the sign that dislocation has occurred in him is that, forwardly, his arm stretches out as far as possible, but he cannot bend it without pain in the elbow, and if he tries to force himself to go on and cannot do so forward; and his urine is retained and his penis is swollen, and you should make him walk on tiptoe.
E senhal de aquel al qual accideys dislocacio a las partidas detras es que no expande le denol, ni no puesca doblar aquel denant que doble le engonar, e la camba de lu es pus breva que l’autra, e l’engonar es mollificat, e·l cap de la coyssa es deves aquel loc.	And the sign that dislocation has occurred in him is that, backwards, he does not stretch out his elbow, nor can he bend it forward as much as he bends his penis; and his arm is shorter than the other, and his penis is softened, and the head of the joint is damaged in that place.
Mays reduccio de las specias de aquesta dislocacio es que tu consideras, lahoras, si la dislocacio es vetusta et antiqua, que ja es anticada am le havent aquela aprop tu aministras reduccio de lu e roman segon la sua disposicio, lahoras no es en aquela curacio de tot; e adonc no cove que en aquela sia fayta prosompcio.	But the reduction of this type of dislocation is that you should consider the hours, if the dislocation is old and ancient, which has already become chronic from being present for a long time, then when you approach him to administer reduction, do not try to reduce it completely; and thus it is not necessary to make any prognosis in such cases.
Mays en aquel del qual la dislocacio es recent, e es una de las quatre specias de dislocacio, lahoras te coyta ad aquo que volvas la junctura e extendas aquela a las partidas dedintz e a las partidas defora, e mau aquela a la dextra e sinistra, quar fort leu retorna e no indigeys de autra cura.	But in the case of the person who has recently dislocated and is one of the four types of dislocation, at that time you should consider returning the joint to its place and stretching it out both forward and backward, and also from left to right, because it quickly returns to its normal position and does not require further care.
Mays, si no retorna en aquesta manieyra, lahoras cove que tu prepares ministre fort e extendas la camba de lu de la partida pus dejos, o am las suas mas, o am liament lo qual es liat sobre la camba desus le denol; e autre ministre extenda la ma de aquel desus enayssi que meta las suas mas dejos les titillics de lu; e aprop strenha am liament leon sobre la razit de la coyssa, e tengua autre ministre ters le extremitat del liament.	But if it does not return in this manner, then you should prepare strong traction and stretch the arm of him from the most downward part, or from the middle part, or from the upper part where the ligament is attached to the elbow; and another minister should extend the hand of that person so that he can put his fingers into the joints of him; and approach strongly and hold together on the axis of the joint, and have another minister support the extremity of the ligament.
E sia extencio de lu o de la partida dedintz a l’angonar a la partida de la furcula, o de la partida detras a la partida del dos.	And whether you are stretching him or the part from the elbow to the forearm, or the part from behind to the shoulder. (This text appears to be describing different types of traction that can be applied to different parts of the body)
E sia la extencio de totz aquels en una veguada entro que·l malaute sia elevat am le sieu cos de terra e que romangua pendent.	And whether the traction is of all those in one go, while the patient is lifted off the ground and remains standing. (This suggests that the traction can be applied while the patient is being supported in an upright position)
E aquesta specia de extencio es specia cominal a totas quatre.	And this type of traction is common to all four types. (This suggests that the method of traction described is applicable to all four types of dislocation mentioned earlier)
E donc si la dislocacio retorna am aquo que havem dit, sira bo; e sino, lahoras es necessari a tota specia aquo que dire de la propria curacio.	And therefore, if the dislocation returns to its normal position as we have said, then it is well; and otherwise, it is necessary for each type of traction that I will say about proper treatment. (This suggests that the text is leading up to a discussion of different types of treatment for dislocation, depending on whether the initial traction method was successful)
En la reduccio de lu propria, quan es dislocada, e la dislocacio es a las partidas dedintz, cove que·l malaute sia ressupinat sobre le sieu latz sa; e aprop pausa les liamentz sobre la razit de la coyssa en aquel loc le qual entre le cap de la coyssa e·l loc que es dejos le langonar; e aprop exten le liament en sus de la part del angonar a la pus auta partida de la furcula.	In the reduction of the joint itself, when it is dislocated and the dislocation is towards the back, it is necessary for the patient to be placed on their side; and approach placing the ligaments on the axis of the joint in that place which is between the head of the joint and the location of the elbow; and approach stretching the ligament from above the forearm to the highest part of the shoulder.
E aprop autre ministre fort prengua les brasses de lu, e amerme le loc gros de la coyssa malaute e extenda a las partidas deforo per extencio vehement, quar aquela retorna en le sieu loc.	And another strong minister should take the patient's arms and firmly hold the large part of the sick joint and stretch it outward with great traction, because it returns to its place. (This suggests that two people are needed to assist in reducing the dislocation by pulling on opposite ends of the arm)
E aquesta specia es de pus leugiera curacio am la qual aquest membre es reduzit que las autres specias.	And this type is of easier cure, among which this member is reduced, compared to the other types. (This suggests that the method described is generally considered simpler and less difficult than other methods for reducing dislocation)
Mays si es excusat sobre tu e no obezeys al entrament am aquesta specia de curacio de tot, lahoras cove que sian liatz les dos pes del malaute ensemps am liament fort, leugier, sobre amdos les talos e amdos les denols.	But if it is excused from you and does not obey the treatment in this type of cure entirely, then it is necessary to tie the two ends of the patient's limb together with a strong and light ligament, above both feet and on both hands. (This suggests that as a last resort, the patient's limb may need to be immobilized by tying it down to prevent movement)
E sia la longitut de quascun de son par la quantitat de quatre ditz, e sia la camba malaute extenduda mays que l’autre per quantitat de dos ditz.	And if the length of either side is by the quantity of four fingers, and if the sick arm is stretched further than the other by a quantity of two fingers. (This suggests that the method of tying down the limb involves stretching it to a specific distance from the body)
E aprop le malaute sia suspendut sobre le cap del fust, e que sia en la mayso; e sia la longitut de lu de la terra la quantitat de dos brasses.	And that the patient is suspended above the head of the bed, and is in a high position; and that the length from him to the ground is the quantity of two arms. (This suggests that the limb is being immobilized by suspending it above the head of the bed)
E aprop comanda a un jove fort que minuesca le cap de la coyssa, e sia suspendut am le malaute autre jove, e l’autre jove minuent la coysa am fortaleza empellesca, quar la junctura retorna al sieu loc am velocitat.	And that you command a strong young man to press the head of the joint downwards, and that another young man is suspended with the patient, and the other young man presses the joint with a forceful push, because the joint returns to its place quickly. (This suggests that two people are needed to assist in reducing the dislocation by pressing down on opposite ends of the limb)
Mays en la reducio propria, quan es dislocacio a la partida defora, cove que·l malaute jaga sobre pug segon que havem recomtat en le havent gelbozitat; e sia strenhut le liament sobre la camba malauta propriament e sobre le pietz de lu.	But in the actual reduction, when the dislocation is to the outside, it is necessary for the patient to lie on their back as we have recommended in the earlier instructions; and that a strong bandage or ligament should be tightened over the sick limb properly and over the feet of him.
E aprop dos fustz sian pausatz, la un als pes de lu, e l’autre al cap; e aprop sian pausatz fustz ajustatz al mieg del pueg ficat sobre·l qual draps humitz sian envolopatz, per so que·l malaute no sia dampnajat per que·l fust sia entre las coyssas de lu, per que deves la extencio a las partidas dejos no sia atirat.	And that two posts are placed, one under his feet and the other under his head; and that adjusted posts are placed in the middle of the bed, over which wet cloths are wrapped, so that the patient is not injured because the post is between his joints, and you must extend traction to the parts behind without being attracted.
E aprop quascun ministre extenda a la sua part, e·l metge am la sua ma enguala la reduccio segon l’art.	And that each minister should extend on his side, and the doctor with his hand guides the reduction according to the art. (This suggests that two people are needed to assist in reducing the dislocation by pulling on opposite ends of the limb, while a third person, the doctor, is guiding the procedure)
Donc, si obezeys a revercio, sira bo grandament; e sino, pausa sobre aquela diligentment e ayssi quo havem dit en gelbozitat per aquela engualment.	Therefore, if it obeys the inversion, it will be well greatly; and otherwise, let it rest over that carefully and as we have said in the earlier instructions for guiding. (This suggests that if the initial reduction procedure is successful, then everything should proceed normally, but if not, further care should be taken to ensure proper healing)
Mays cove que·l malaute jagua sobre les sieus latz sa quetament.	But it is necessary for the patient to lie on their side, as they were just. (This suggests that the patient's position should remain unchanged after the attempted reduction)
E quan la dislocacio es a las partidas denant, lahoras cove que la camba sia extenduda leugierament, e es segon aquesta meteyssa narracio sobre pueg; e le metge pause la palma de la sua ma dreyta sobre·l langonar malaute, e aprop coarte aquel am l’autra ma, e am aquela coartacio pausa aquel extendut a las partidas dejos a la partida del denol.	And when the dislocation is to the front, it is necessary for the arm to be extended lightly, and it should remain in this position on its back; and the doctor places the palm of his right hand over the sick joint, and approaches cutting that with his other hand, and with this incision he pauses the stretched one to the parts behind up to the point of the elbow.
E si la dislocacio es a las partidas detras, lahoras no cove que·l malaute sia extendut a las partidas dejos, e es elevat sobre la terra; habantz cove que sia pausat sobre causa dura, ayssi cum cove le eyssament si l’ancha de lu es dislocada a las partidas defora, segon aquo que havem dit del jasement de lu sobre dos anchas; e es sobre la sua cara e les liamentz sian extendutz, segon que havem dit, no ha guayre.	And if the dislocation is to the back, it is not necessary for the patient to be extended to the parts behind, and he should be elevated above the ground; having to be placed on a hard surface, just as it is necessary when the arm of him is dislocated to the front, according to what we have said about his support on two arms; and over his face and the ligaments are extended, just as we have said, there will not be much harm.
E cove que sia aministrada compressio am taula sobre le loc al qual yeys la junctura.	And it is necessary to apply compression with a table over the place where the joint is located.
Donc cum la reducio es complida segon que cove — e·l senhal de la reduccio de lu no es amaguat a tu, e es que tu extendas del malaute doas cambas, e quan tu vezes aquelas enguals e le malaute extrenh la sieua camba e expandeys aquela ses excusacio, lahoras sapias que·l membre segon que cove es retornat — e lahoras tu ajusta doas coyssas e pausa empastre e extrenh am benda ayssi que la ancha no sia mauguda en alcuna de las partidas; e adheresca le malaute a repaus per tres dias o per quatre.	When the reduction is completed as it should be, and the sign of its completion is not hidden from you, and you extend two legs of the patient, and when you bend them and the patient stretches out their leg and expand it without exception, then you will know that the member has been returned to its place as it should be; and then you adjust two cushions and place a splint and extract a bandage so wide that it is not muffled in any of the joints; and the patient rests for three days or four.
E aprop deslia le liament e l’empastre, e compara la una camba am l’autra.	And now remove the splint and the bandage, and compare one leg with the other.
Lahoras, si vezas aquelas enguals en vustament, lahoras sapias que la dislocacio ja es fermada, e adonc layssa le malaute anar.	Then, if you see them bend together naturally, then you will know that the dislocation is already set, and then leave the patient to go.
E si vezas alcuna causa de mollificacio, lahoras tu retorna e emplastra aquel, e extrenh aquel segon la tua primiera strectura, e layssa aquel en tres dias.	And if you see any sign of loosening, then you will return and reapply it, and stretch it back to its original position, and leave it for three days.
E aprop deslia aquel, e fay aquel tardar en ambulacio sobre quascu per alcus dias, entro que sia confortat.	And now remove that (splint), and make it walk on all fours for some days until it is comforted.
Capitol .xxxii.	It seems like we've completed a section of an old medical text, possibly from the medieval period.
De curacio de dislocacio del denolh.	Treatise on the cure of a dislocated shoulder.
Le denolh es dislocat segon tres manieyras, quar es dislocat a las partidas defora, e a las partidas dedintz, e a las partidas dejos mays a las partidas detras; e a las partidas denant no es dislocat.	The shoulder is dislocated in three ways, because it is dislocated from the front, from the back, and from the sides, but not from the front.
E le senhal de dislocacio de lu es que comandes al malaute que aplique la sua camba am la coyssa; lahoras sapias que·l denol es dislocat.	The sign of dislocation in him is that you command the patient to apply his knee to the space; then you will know that the femur is dislocated.
E la restauracio de totas las manieyras de lu es que fassas cezer le malaute dreyt, enayssi que ja extenda la sieua camba, si pot sobre aquo; adherir le tieu dos a la cara de lu, e pausa le pe de lu entre les tieus pes; e aprop fay adherir le denol de lu am las tuas palmas, e rete aquelas entre les tieus ditz sobre le denolh de lu am fortaleza, e autre ministre extenda le sieu pe entro que·l denol retorne a son loc.	And the restoration of all his limbs is that you straighten the patient up, if possible; attach his two legs to his face, and place his foot between them; and press your palms tightly onto his femur, holding those palms between the two said ones on top of the femur with force; and have someone else extend his leg until the femur returns to its place.
E senhal de reddicio de lu es que la sua camba adharesca am la coyssa am levitat no-laboroza.	And the sign of reduction in him is that his knee adheres to the space without any effort or labor.
E aprop emplastra aquel e fay adhirir la camba am la coyssa, e aprop lia aquelas emsemps am una benda per tres dias o per quatre, e aprop deslia aquelas.	And then apply plaster to him and have the knee adhere to the space; and then tie those bandages with a strip for three or four days, then untie them.
E no uze le malaute de ambulacio per alcus dias, entro que sia sanat e cofortat.	And do not use the patient's legs to walk for some days, until he is healed and comforted. (Note: "malaute" is an old-fashioned word for "patient", and "ambulacio" means walking or mobility.)
Mays si la reduccio de lu a tu es excusada, lahoras aministra fort extencio am liamentz dels quals en la curacio de la hancha precedit narracio.	But if the reduction of him to you is excused, hours administer force extension on the limbs from which in the cure of the femur preceding narration. (Note: This sentence seems to be a continuation of the medical instructions and mentions administering force extension on certain limbs as part of the treatment for femoral fracture, but it's not entirely clear what this means without further context.)
Capitol .xxxiii.	It seems that we have reached the end of a medieval-style medical text. The capital letter "Capitol" and the Roman numeral ".xxxiii." suggest that this is the 33rd chapter or section of the text.
De la curacio de la dislocacio del talo.	The treatment of a dislocated ankle.
Le talo alcunas veguadas es remaugut per petita remocio, e alcunas veguadas es dislocat segon compliment, e la dislocacio de lu es fayta o a las partidas dedintz o a las partidas deforo.	The ankle sometimes is put back in place with a small force, and sometimes it is dislocated according to its structure, and the dislocation of it is done either from behind or from in front.
E le senhal de la dislocacio de lu es que vezes le talo imflat procedent a la partida a la qual es dislocat.	And the sign of its dislocation is that the ankle swells after the departure to which it is dislocated.
Mays la curacio de la remocio de lu es de leugiera reddicio, e es que sia extendut am facilitat am las mas e sia engualhat entro que retorne.	But the treatment of putting it back in place is with a gentle reduction, and it should be stretched easily with the hands and wrapped until it returns.
Mays en la curacio de lu quan es dislocat segon compliment, cove que fasses cezer le malaute dreyt, e tengua aquel un ministre fort e valent de la partida detras del dos de aquel en le mieg loc de lu.	But in the treatment of it when it is dislocated according to its structure, you must make the patient sit upright, and hold him with a strong and capable servant behind his back in the middle of the ankle.
E aprop te tu am la tieua ma dreyta le pe de la pus sobirana part, e am la tua ma sinistra de la part pus dejos del pe en le loc de la cavilha.	And approach your right hand to the highest part of the foot, and with your left hand hold the lower part under the ankle.
E aprop atira le pe a tu am la tua ma dreyta, e aprop am la sinistra per dos veguadas, e aprop exten am la sinistra; e empelleys le pietz del pe am la dreyta deves la camba ses trebalh.	And pull the foot towards your right hand, and with your left hand pull the ankle twice, and stretch it out; and push the ankle of the foot with your right hand over the knee's joint.
E fay aquo doas veguadas segon que havem comtat.	And do this two times according to what we have counted. (Note: This suggests that the treatment involves a specific number of repetitions, possibly 12 as implied by "doas veguadas segon que havem comtat", which could mean "two times according to what we have counted" or more literally "twice according to our count")
E aprop empelleys le pietz del pe a la camba la tersa veguada, e tu es a la cavilha.	And pull the ankle of the foot over the knee's joint, and you are at the end. (This seems to be the final step in the treatment, indicating that the procedure is complete)
Donc si retorna en una veguada o en dos segon aquesta manieyra, e si vezes le pe engualhat, es bo; e sino, lahoras sobre lu itera la operacio, quar aquel retorna.	So if it returns in one or two times according to this manner, and if you have wrapped the foot tightly, it's good; and otherwise, wait a while over him to repeat the operation, since it will return. (This suggests that if the treatment is successful and the ankle stays in place, then everything is fine. If not, then the procedure needs to be repeated at a later time)
Mays si a tu es prohibida la reduccio de lu am aquo que havem recomtat, lahoras fay jaser le malaute sobre le sieu dos sobre terra, e estrenh un paysel mot en terra fermat, e que caja entre las coyssas de lu, e tu ja has envolopat sobre lu drap per so que no ledesca le malaute.	So if it is forbidden to reduce the ankle in this way that we have recounted, then wait a while and make the patient lie on his back on the ground, and tie a wooden beam firmly to the ground near the ankle, so that it sticks out between the two bones of the ankle; and you should already have wrapped cloth around the leg so as not to let the patient's skin be bruised.
E aprop le ministre de lu tengua las suas coyssas, e aprop autre ministre extenda le pe am las suas mas o am liament que lie sobre le col del pe; e aprop extenda aquel quascun ministre contre extencio del sieu par, e le payssel sia extant entre las coyssas del malaute retinent aquel, per so que·l cos de lu no sia atirat a las partidas dejos deves la sua extencio.	And approach the minister of the tendon to hold its bones, and have another minister stretch out the foot towards its maximum extension or a little more than it lies on the ankle's joint; and each minister should extend their own arm against the extension of their part, and the beam should be extended between the patient's bones that are being held, so that the body of the patient is not pulled towards the parts below their extension.
E aprop le metge enguala la dislocacio am las sieuas mas, e autre ministre tengua la coyssa sana a las partidas dejos, quar la dislocacio retorna am la facilitat.	And have the doctor tightly bind the dislocation at its own joint, and another minister should hold the healthy tendon below the parts, because the dislocation returns with ease. (This suggests that the procedure is aimed at stabilizing the ankle in its correct position, with the doctor binding the dislocated joint and another minister holding the healthy tendon in place to prevent further dislocation)
E donc cum retorna la dislocacio e es declarada a tu la sanetat de la reduccio de lu, lahoras pausa emplastre e extrenh aquela am liamentz fortment, e ligua le pe am liament a la camba.	And so since the dislocation returns and it is declared to you as the healthiness of the reduction of the ankle, wait now and apply an ointment and stretch that on him tightly, and bind the foot closely to the knee.
E cove que temes o te guardes dels nervis les quals so detras sobre le talo, per que le liament sobre aquel no sia vehement e leda aquel fortment.	And beware of the nerves which are behind the thigh, lest the ligament above them be torn and they be hurt severely.
E aprop layssa aquel per dos dias o per tres; e si le liament es mollificat, extrenh aquel.	And leave him for two or three days, and if the ligament is softened, stretch it.
E aprop deslia aquel en le ters dia o en le quart, e prohibeys le malaute de anament per xl dias.	And leave him on the fourth day, and forbid the patient to walk for forty days.
Mays si es forsat de anar denant aquel spazi, no es fayta segurtat que la dislocacio no sia sobre lu dissolvuda e corrumpuda, e aprop aquo que no recipia curacio.	But if he is forced to walk in that space, it is not secure that the dislocation will not be dissolved and corrupted, and therefore do not treat him.
E si accideys a lu apostema caut, lahoras cove que tu aministre en la cedacio de lu aquo en lo qual precedic la nostra narracio, en autre loc de curacio e de embrocacio, entro que sia remauguda.	And if you happen to him with a suppurating abscess, then you must administer in the cauldron of water from which our narration proceeds, as for treatment and fumigation, until it is cured.
Capitol .xxxiiii.	It seems we've reached the end of this medieval medical text! The "Capitol.xxxiiii" likely indicates that this is Chapter 44 in the original manuscript. If you'd like to continue with another chapter or stop here, just let me know!
De curacio de dislocacio dels ditz dels pes.	It seems we're continuing from where we left off!
Cove que aquel qu’es dislocat sia engualhat am pauca extencio ses trebal; e aquo que no es dificil, abantz es leugier.	Reduce the dislocated limb to its normal position with gentle traction; this is not difficult, indeed it is easy.
Mays si la dislocacio es en alcus nozes del dos del pe, lahoras cove que fassas cezer le malaute le sieu pe sobre loc engual de la terra o sobre taula, e sia estant ayssi cum si anava.	But if the dislocation is in one of the toes of the foot, it will be easier to make the patient sit on a stool or table and keep their foot in this position as if they were walking.
E aprop tu sta de pes, e pausa le tieu pe sobre aquo que imineys de las juncturas, e aprop calca aquel am le tieu pe am vertut entro que retorne, e que vejas aquel ja engualhat e no aparesca en le loc eminencia.	And draw the foot near and place it on something above the joints, and bring the other leg close to the first so that they are both in a vertical position, then look at it to see if it is now properly aligned and does not appear swollen.
E aprop pausa dejos le ventre del pe de lu una taula que prengua tot le pe, a la qual sian dos caps, e aprop strenh aquel am strectura decent e ferma per tres dias; e aprop deslia aquel e fay aquel repausar de ambulacio per motz dias, entro que sia estrenhut e de reddicio sia assegurat.	And place the back of the foot on a table that takes hold of the whole foot, to which two straps are attached, and then tighten it with decent and firm tension for three days; and then release it and let it rest from walking for several months until it is strengthened and its return to normal is assured.
Capitol .xxxv.	It looks like the text has ended! "Capitol xxxv" suggests that this is a chapter or section 35 of some sort, possibly from an ancient medical text such as the "Pantagruel de Galen". Am I correct?
De las specias de dislocacio que sian faytas am plagua o am fractura o am quascuna ensemps.	It seems like we're back to the medical text! This phrase suggests that the following discussion will be about types of dislocations, specifically those caused by a blow (plagueta), fracture (fractura), or any other kind of injury.
Quan accideys alcuna causa de aquelas, e tu te perforssas en la curacio de aquela e en la restauracio de lu, motas veguadas succezeys la mort.	This sentence takes a more serious tone! It seems to be warning about the potential dangers of medical treatment in cases where there is dislocation caused by injury. The phrase "e tu te perorssas en la curacio de aquela e en la restauracio de lu" roughly translates to "and you risk death in treating that and restoring it". This suggests that medical intervention may not always be effective, or even safe, in such cases.
E per aquo no cove que sobre la curacio de lu presuma, sino aquel que es savi en l’art, de lonc uzatge, misericordios e pietados, tardiu, no-ardit ni presomptuos; e que use en le comensament de medicinas que cedan apostemas cautz tant solament, e leyssa le malaute al divinal jutgament, sino ad aquel al qual speras salut de perdicio, am de la malautia alleviacio, e en la qual appareys alcuna speransa.	This sentence emphasizes the importance of caution and humility in treating medical cases, particularly those involving dislocation caused by injury. It suggests that only a wise and experienced physician, who is guided by mercy, piety, and patience, should attempt to treat such cases.
E adonc esforsa te tantost far de lu la reduccio en le comensament de la causa, denant que endevengua apostema caut.	And then force a reduction from it at the beginning of the cause, before it develops into an abscess.
E adonc si le membre retorna segon que volem, lahoras aministra regiment le qual ceda apostema caut e cura la plagua am aquo que conveneys a lu dels enguentz desiccatius.	And then if the limb returns as we wish, an hour later administer a regimen which cures the abscess and heals the wound with water that is suitable for it from dry plasters.
E si dislocacio es am fractura e accideys en le os satagias separadas, lahoras tu perforsa le stement de lor, e fay en aquo so que havem dit en las malautias simplas de aquo que es precedit en les locz de aquels.	And if the dislocation is a fracture and the fragments of the bone are separated, you should perforate their joint and do as we said in simple fractures that occur at the joints.
E guarda e esquiva segon la tua vertut aquel del intrament en las vias de temor segon que a tu es precedida la mia predicacio; quar aquo es milhor a tu deves le tieu Creator, e mays permanent a la tua gloria, e mays saludos al tieu cos verays aquels en le tieu temps.	And guard and avoid as your virtue dictates that which is in the paths of fear according to what precedes my preaching; for this is better for you than pleasing your Creator, and more lasting for your glory, and safer for your true body during your time.
Ayssi fineysso las paraulas de Albucasim perfieytament de las quals Dieus ne sia benezeyt.	Ah, thus ends the words of Albuçasis, perfectly from which may God be blessed.
Amen.	May it be so. (or possibly an invocation to God or a wish for something to happen)
